questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of intermittent shortness of breath and palpitations. The episodes are unprovoked and occur randomly. The day before, he felt lightheaded while walking and had to sit down abruptly to avoid passing out. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Cardiac catheterization 5 years ago showed occlusion of the left anterior descending artery, and he underwent placement of a stent. He does not drink alcohol or use any illicit drugs. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and clopidogrel. He appears well. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a rapid, irregular rhythm. He suddenly feels lightheaded and sits in a chair to avoid falling. An ECG of this episode is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Anomalous conduction through an accessory pathway
Dissociation of the atria and ventricles

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conduction delay of an electrical impulse through the atrioventricular (AV) node is referred to as first-degree AV block. The hallmark of AV block on ECG is an abnormally long PR interval (> 0.2 seconds), representing the delay between atrial and ventricular depolarization. Although this patient is on a medication that can cause first-degree AV block (metoprolol), the PR intervals in this patient's ECG are within normal range, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, AV block is not associated with tachycardia.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Normal sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼80/min
– Normal axis
– PR interval: ∼300 ms

The PR interval >200 ms indicates first-degree atrioventricular block.

B) INCORRECT:

Premature ventricular contractions can cause palpitations and dyspnea. Although they can occur in healthy adults, palpitations and dyspnea are more common in patients with underlying ischemic heart disease. However, ECG would show occasional irregular, wide QRS complexes with a subsequent compensatory pause (usually the pause is twice the length of the preceding RR interval).
Image Description:

ECG rhythm strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm (blue overlay: heart rate approx. 95 bpm; narrow QRS complexes) with frequent PVCs (monomorphic QRS complexes approx. 440 ms wide)
– Top strip: trigeminy (a repeating pattern of one PVC after every two sinus beats)
– Middle strip: two short runs of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT; yellow overlay: heart rate approx.150 bpm) and one PVC couplet (green overlay)
– Bottom strip: one short run of NSVT, two PVC couplets, and a fusion complex (red overlay)

C) INCORRECT:

Anomalous conduction through an accessory pathway in the heart can lead to atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia (AVRT), as seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. Although WPW syndrome may also cause intermittent tachycardia with palpitations and dyspnea, it is characterized on ECG by tachycardia, with a short PR interval and classic Delta wave upstroke on the QRS, best seen in lead V4. In other forms of AVRT, a retrograde P wave is often seen after the QRS. This patient's underlying cardiac comorbidities and evidence of bradycardia point to another diagnosis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

D) INCORRECT:

Abnormal automaticity or reentry circuits within the ventricle are characteristic of ventricular tachycardia (V-tach) or ventricular fibrillation (V-fib), two life-threatening rhythms that are most commonly related to underlying ischemic heart disease. Similar to this patient, non-sustained V-tach may initially present with episodic palpitations and dyspnea. However, ECG would show broad QRS complexes without discernible P waves.
Image Description:

Single-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: 192/min
– Regular rhythm
– No P or T waves are discernible because of the high ventricular rate.
– QRS complexes are broad (> 120 ms) and monomorphic (there is a similar QRS morphology in all beats).

These features are characteristic of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT persisting for ≥ 30 seconds is considered sustained VT (this strip does not show the full 30-second interval).

E) CORRECT:

Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) refers to sinus node dysfunction and is most commonly caused by age-related degeneration and fibrosis, leading to abnormal automaticity (generation of electrical impulse) and/or abnormal conduction. SSS may also be caused or exacerbated by medications, including beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol). Diagnosis can be challenging, as arrhythmias are often transient and not always captured on 12-lead ECG. If clinical suspicion is high and ECG is unrevealing, a Holter monitor or event monitor should be considered to confirm the diagnosis. This patient's symptoms of cerebral hypoperfusion (presyncope) and evidence of bradycardia with sinus pause are enough to confirm the diagnosis. Palpitations, dyspnea, and irregular tachycardia on examination suggest that he has tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome.

Symptomatic SSS is an indication for pacemaker placement.

F) INCORRECT:

Dissociation of the atria and ventricles is characteristic of third-degree atrioventricular block, which may manifest with bradycardia, dyspnea, and syncope or presyncope. However, episodes of tachycardia would not be expected in this condition, and ECG would show a complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with each occurring at regular intervals independent of one another.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate: ∼ 110/min
– Ventricular rate: ∼ 27/min (escape rhythm)
– QRS complex: ∼ 100 ms (normal)
– AV dissociation: P waves (black arrowheads) and QRS complexes (red arrowheads) both have regular rhythms, but the rhythms are unrelated because there is no conduction between the atria and ventricles. This results in some P waves being completely or partially buried in QRS complexes or T waves (green arrowheads).

AV dissociation with bradycardia is characteristic of third-degree atrioventricular block (complete heart block).

G) INCORRECT:

Multifocal atrial tachycardia due to a wandering atrial pacemaker can cause symptoms of palpitations and dyspnea. A wandering atrial pacemaker is more common in patients with underlying pulmonary disease (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic hypoxemia, pulmonary hypertension), but can also occur with a comorbid cardiac disease, including coronary artery disease. ECG findings show changing P wave morphology (at least three different P wave morphologies must be present) and PR interval durations, neither of which is present on this patient's ECG.
questions.hint: This patient presents with palpitations and presyncope, and while initially tachycardic, his ECG shows sinus bradycardia with sinus pause, followed by an escape rhythm. This suggests a diagnosis that is more common in older patients with comorbid heart disease.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man with a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia, currently taking amlodipine and atorvastatin, presents to the emergency department after a witnessed episode of loss of consciousness. He reports that he was standing up from a nap when he felt lightheaded and fell to the ground without any major trauma. He regained consciousness immediately and did not notice any change from his baseline status. On further questioning, he describes 3 months of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion, with no chest pain. He had previously been quite active and would bicycle up to 4 miles a few times per week.
On examination, he has a regular heart rate of 48 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 164/92 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while breathing ambient air. He has no murmurs and faint bibasilar crackles. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
His electrocardiogram is shown (figure).
A complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and measurement of high-sensitivity troponin, brain-type natriuretic peptide, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are all within normal limits.
An echocardiogram shows normal left- and right-ventricular function with no significant valvular disease.
The patient is currently asymptomatic at rest. His heart rate on telemetry ranges from 32 to 48 beats per minute when he is at rest and when he walks to the bathroom with assistance or ambulates with the physical therapy team.
Which one of the following management steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue the amlodipine, and switch to losartan
Discharge with outpatient follow-up with primary care provider if there is no evidence of high-grade atrioventricular nodal block on 24-hour telemetry
Consult cardiology for placement of a permanent pacemaker

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A trial of atropine would be reasonable in a patient with active, moderate-to-severe symptoms of bradycardia (shortness of breath, chest pain, altered mental status, hemodynamic compromise) to improve their heart rate and reduce symptoms. However, it is not indicated in this patient, who is currently asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable while at rest in the hospital.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain calcium-channel blockers can cause bradycardia, but dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers such as amlodipine do not have this effect; there is therefore no indication to switch this patient’s amlodipine to losartan.

C) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine or dopamine infusions and temporary cardiac pacing (transcutaneous or transvenous) are usually considered only in hemodynamically unstable bradycardia if atropine is ineffective and would therefore not be indicated in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Although high-grade atrioventricular block, even in the absence of symptoms, is an indication for a permanent pacemaker, this patient already has an indication for permanent pacing. It would therefore not be appropriate to discharge him without a pacemaker.

E) CORRECT:

The most remarkable finding on this patient’s evaluation is the sinus bradycardia, which is evident on electrocardiogram and persists on telemetry even with exertion. Bradycardia can manifest with symptoms that range from fatigue and exercise intolerance to frank syncope, with the severity of symptoms directly related to the heart rate. Patients with symptomatic sinus bradycardia should have the following potential causes ruled out: use of certain medications (beta-blockers, nondihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers, antiarrhythmics, and cholinesterase inhibitors), sleep apnea, hypothyroidism, acute myocardial infarction, and electrolyte abnormalities.

If all of these causes have been ruled out (as in this case), the most likely cause of sinus bradycardia in an older adult is sinus node dysfunction, which is thought to be caused by increased collagen content and fibrosis around the sinoatrial node. The condition is typically treated with placement of a permanent pacemaker.

Key learning point: Patients with symptoms directly attributable to sinus node dysfunction and no contributing reversible causes should undergo permanent pacemaker implantation to increase their heart rate and improve symptoms.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man with a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia, currently taking amlodipine and atorvastatin, presents to the emergency department after a witnessed episode of loss of consciousness. Over the past 3 months he has experienced progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion, with no chest pain. On physical examination, his pulse is 48/min, blood pressure is 164/92 mm Hg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% while breathing ambient air. His electrocardiogram is shown. A complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and measurement of high-sensitivity troponin, brain-type natriuretic peptide, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are all within normal limits. An echocardiogram shows normal left- and right-ventricular function with no significant valvular disease. The patient is currently asymptomatic at rest. His heart rate on telemetry ranges from 32 to 48 beats per minute when he is at rest and when he walks to the bathroom with assistance. Which one of the following management steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue the amlodipine, and switch to losartan
Discharge with outpatient follow-up with primary care provider if there is no evidence of high-grade atrioventricular nodal block on 24-hour telemetry
Consult cardiology for placement of a permanent pacemaker

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A trial of atropine would be reasonable in a patient with active, moderate-to-severe symptoms of bradycardia (shortness of breath, chest pain, altered mental status, hemodynamic compromise) to improve their heart rate and reduce symptoms. However, it is not indicated in this patient, who is currently asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable while at rest in the hospital.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain calcium-channel blockers can cause bradycardia, but dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers such as amlodipine do not have this effect; there is therefore no indication to switch this patient’s amlodipine to losartan.

C) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine or dopamine infusions and temporary cardiac pacing (transcutaneous or transvenous) are usually considered only in hemodynamically unstable bradycardia if atropine is ineffective and would therefore not be indicated in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Although high-grade atrioventricular block, even in the absence of symptoms, is an indication for a permanent pacemaker, this patient already has an indication for permanent pacing. It would therefore not be appropriate to discharge him without a pacemaker.

E) CORRECT:

The most remarkable finding on this patient’s evaluation is the sinus bradycardia, which is evident on electrocardiogram and persists on telemetry even with exertion. Bradycardia can manifest with symptoms that range from fatigue and exercise intolerance to frank syncope, with the severity of symptoms directly related to the heart rate. Patients with symptomatic sinus bradycardia should have the following potential causes ruled out: use of certain medications (beta-blockers, nondihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers, antiarrhythmics, and cholinesterase inhibitors), sleep apnea, hypothyroidism, acute myocardial infarction, and electrolyte abnormalities.

If all of these causes have been ruled out (as in this case), the most likely cause of sinus bradycardia in an older adult is sinus node dysfunction, which is thought to be caused by increased collagen content and fibrosis around the sinoatrial node. The condition is typically treated with placement of a permanent pacemaker.

Key learning point: Patients with symptoms directly attributable to sinus node dysfunction and no contributing reversible causes should undergo permanent pacemaker implantation to increase their heart rate and improve symptoms.
questions.hint: Sinus node dysfunction (SND) is most commonly caused by age-related degeneration and fibrosis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the office because of an episode of lightheadedness yesterday while walking, during which he had to sit down abruptly to avoid passing out. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. He does not drink alcohol or use any illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and clopidogrel. Pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mm Hg. Findings on physical examination are normal. During the examination, he suddenly feels lightheaded and sits down to avoid falling. Electrocardiography obtained during this episode is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The hallmark of first-degree AV block on ECG is an abnormally long PR interval (> 0.2 seconds), representing the delay between atrial and ventricular depolarization. Although this patient is on a medication that can cause first-degree AV block (metoprolol), the PR intervals in this patient's ECG are within normal range, making this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, first-degree AV block is usually asymptomatic.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Normal sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼80/min
– Normal axis
– PR interval: ∼300 ms

The PR interval >200 ms indicates first-degree atrioventricular block.

B) INCORRECT:

Second-degree AV block may manifest with bradycardia and symptoms such as syncope or presyncope. A second-degree AV block can manifest as either a Mobitz type 1 or a Mobitz type 2 block. Mobitz type 1 manifests with a progressive prolongation of the PR interval that culminates in a nonconducted P wave (“dropped beat”) on ECG. Mobitz type 2 AV block is characterized by a constant PR interval and a single or intermittent nonconducted P wave without subsequent QRS complexes.

C) INCORRECT:

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is characterized on ECG by tachycardia, with a short PR interval and classic Delta wave upstroke on the QRS, best seen in lead V4. This patient's underlying cardiac comorbidities and evidence of bradycardia point to another diagnosis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

D) CORRECT:

Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) refers to sinus node dysfunction and is most commonly caused by age-related degeneration and fibrosis, leading to abnormal automaticity (generation of electrical impulse) and/or abnormal conduction. SSS may also be caused or exacerbated by medications, including beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol). Diagnosis can be challenging, as arrhythmias are often transient and not always captured on 12-lead ECG. If clinical suspicion is high and ECG is unrevealing, a Holter monitor or event monitor should be considered to confirm the diagnosis. This patient's symptoms of cerebral hypoperfusion (presyncope) and evidence of bradycardia with sinus pause are enough to confirm the diagnosis.

Symptomatic SSS is an indication for pacemaker placement.

E) INCORRECT:

Third-degree atrioventricular block may manifest with bradycardia and syncope or presyncope. However, ECG would show a complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with each occurring at regular intervals independent of one another.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate: ∼ 110/min
– Ventricular rate: ∼ 27/min (escape rhythm)
– QRS complex: ∼ 100 ms (normal)
– AV dissociation: P waves (black arrowheads) and QRS complexes (red arrowheads) both have regular rhythms, but the rhythms are unrelated because there is no conduction between the atria and ventricles. This results in some P waves being completely or partially buried in QRS complexes or T waves (green arrowheads).

AV dissociation with bradycardia is characteristic of third-degree atrioventricular block (complete heart block).
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows sinus bradycardia with sinus pause, followed by an escape rhythm. This suggests a diagnosis that is more common in older patients with comorbid heart disease.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to your clinic after experiencing an episode of lightheadedness yesterday while walking, during which he had to sit down abruptly to avoid passing out. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. His current medications are aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and clopidogrel. Pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mm Hg. Physical examination is normal. During your assessment, he suddenly feels lightheaded and sits down to avoid falling. Electrocardiography obtained during this episode is shown. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) refers to sinus node dysfunction and is most commonly caused by age-related degeneration and fibrosis, leading to abnormal automaticity (generation of electrical impulse) and/or abnormal conduction. SSS may also be caused or exacerbated by medications, including beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol). Diagnosis can be challenging, as arrhythmias are often transient and not always captured on 12-lead ECG. If clinical suspicion is high and ECG is unrevealing, a Holter monitor or event monitor should be considered to confirm the diagnosis. This patient's symptoms of cerebral hypoperfusion (presyncope) and evidence of bradycardia with sinus pause are enough to confirm the diagnosis.

Symptomatic SSS is an indication for pacemaker placement.

Key learning point: Sick sinus syndrome is caused by sinus node dysfunction, often due to age-related degeneration, and presents with transient bradyarrhythmias leading to symptoms like presyncope or syncope.

B) INCORRECT:

The hallmark of first-degree AV block on ECG is an abnormally long PR interval (> 0.2 seconds), representing the delay between atrial and ventricular depolarization. Although this patient is on a medication that can cause first-degree AV block (metoprolol), the PR intervals in this patient's ECG are within normal range, making this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, first-degree AV block is usually asymptomatic.

C) INCORRECT:

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is characterized on ECG by tachycardia, with a short PR interval and classic Delta wave upstroke on the QRS, best seen in lead V4. This patient's underlying cardiac comorbidities and evidence of bradycardia point to another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Third-degree atrioventricular block may manifest with bradycardia and syncope or presyncope. However, ECG would show a complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with each occurring at regular intervals independent of one another.

E) INCORRECT:

Second-degree AV block may manifest with bradycardia and symptoms such as syncope or presyncope. A second-degree AV block can manifest as either a Mobitz type 1 or a Mobitz type 2 block. Mobitz type 1 manifests with a progressive prolongation of the PR interval that culminates in a nonconducted P wave (“dropped beat”) on ECG. Mobitz type 2 AV block is characterized by a constant PR interval and a single or intermittent nonconducted P wave without subsequent QRS complexes.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows sinus bradycardia with sinus pause, followed by an escape rhythm. This suggests a diagnosis that is more common in older patients with comorbid heart disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the ED with a 3-day history of progressive fatigue and lightheadedness. He reports taking metoprolol for hypertension and had one episode of near-syncope this morning while getting out of bed. His wife notes he has been moving more slowly than usual. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 38; R, 16; oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. He appears tired but is alert and oriented. A rhythm strip is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain thyroid function tests and basic metabolic panel
Perform echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function
Administer IV atropine and prepare for transcutaneous pacing
Discontinue metoprolol and observe for 24 hours
Order Holter monitor and schedule cardiology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While evaluation for reversible causes such as hypothyroidism is important in sinus node dysfunction, this patient's hypotension with bradycardia indicates hemodynamic instability, requiring immediate intervention before diagnostic studies.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography may be useful to evaluate for structural heart disease as an underlying cause, but it is not the priority in a hemodynamically unstable patient who needs immediate stabilization for bradycardia.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has unstable bradycardia, evidenced by hypotension (systolic BP < 90 mm Hg) and symptoms of end-organ hypoperfusion. The combination of severe bradycardia and hemodynamic compromise requires immediate treatment with IV atropine and preparation for transcutaneous pacing per ACLS protocols. Reversible causes can be addressed after stabilization.

D) INCORRECT:

Although beta-blocker toxicity is a potential reversible cause of sinus node dysfunction, simply discontinuing metoprolol without immediate stabilization is inappropriate in a hemodynamically unstable patient with severe bradycardia.

E) INCORRECT:

Holter monitoring is appropriate for stable patients with suspected sinus node dysfunction to correlate symptoms with rhythm abnormalities. This hemodynamically unstable patient requires immediate intervention rather than outpatient monitoring.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with diabetes and hypertension presents with progressive fatigue and two episodes of near-syncope over the past month. He takes metformin, lisinopril, and metoprolol. His ECG is shown. Vital signs are P, 35; BP, 110/65. Laboratory results show creatinine 1.2 mg/dL and thyroid-stimulating hormone 2.1 mIU/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ECG shows sinus pauses (∼ 3.8 seconds) with junctional escape beats and normal PR intervals when P waves are present. The prolonged sinus pauses (> 3 seconds) followed by junctional escape rhythms are classic findings of sinus node dysfunction, representing inappropriate impulse generation by the SA node.

B) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus pauses (∼ 3.8 seconds) with junctional escape beats and normal PR intervals when P waves are present. The normal P waves with appropriate PR intervals when sinus beats occur are inconsistent with third-degree AV block, which would show complete AV dissociation with no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes.

C) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus pauses (∼ 3.8 seconds) with junctional escape beats and normal PR intervals when P waves are present. The discrete, normal P waves with consistent PR intervals are inconsistent with atrial fibrillation, which would show fibrillatory waves and an irregularly irregular rhythm without discrete P waves.

D) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus pauses (∼ 3.8 seconds) with junctional escape beats and normal PR intervals when P waves are present. Normal electrolytes exclude hypokalemia, and the sinus pause pattern is inconsistent with hypokalemia, which typically causes flattened T waves, U waves, and ST depression rather than sinus pauses with junctional escape rhythms.

E) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus pauses (∼ 3.8 seconds) with junctional escape beats and normal PR intervals when P waves are present. The normal PR intervals are inconsistent with second-degree AV block, which requires prolonged PR intervals with dropped QRS complexes following P waves.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of increasing fatigue and two episodes of lightheadedness while climbing stairs. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath at rest, or loss of consciousness. Medical history includes well-controlled diabetes. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 45; R 18; oxygen saturation 98% on room air. He is alert and oriented. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. ECG is shown. Laboratory studies, including electrolytes, thyroid function, and troponin, are normal. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge home with primary care follow-up in one week
Keep in observation unit overnight and discharge if asymptomatic tomorrow
Obtain immediate cardiology consultation for pacemaker evaluation
Admit to hospital on telemetry and consult cardiology if abnormal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus node dysfunction with pauses > 3 seconds and junctional escape rhythm. Primary care follow-up alone is insufficient for symptomatic sinus node dysfunction with documented rhythm abnormalities. This patient requires specialist evaluation for potential permanent pacemaker placement given the correlation between symptoms and bradyarrhythmia.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The ECG shows sinus node dysfunction (SND) with pauses > 3 seconds and junctional escape rhythm. He is hemodynamically stable with systolic BP ≥ 90 mm Hg and without severe symptoms (no syncope, angina, or hypotension), so outpatient management is appropriate. However, the documented rhythm abnormalities with correlating symptoms require prompt cardiology evaluation within 2–3 days to assess for permanent pacemaker placement, which is first-line treatment for symptomatic SND.

C) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus node dysfunction with pauses > 3 seconds and junctional escape rhythm. Observation alone does not address the underlying issue of symptomatic sinus node dysfunction. This patient needs specialist evaluation to determine if permanent pacemaker placement is indicated, not just monitoring for symptom resolution.

D) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus node dysfunction with pauses > 3 seconds and junctional escape rhythm. Inpatient cardiology consultation is reserved for patients with severe symptoms (recurrent syncope, angina) or systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg. This stable patient with exertional symptoms but normal blood pressure can be managed with urgent outpatient cardiology referral.

E) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows sinus node dysfunction with pauses > 3 seconds and junctional escape rhythm. This patient is hemodynamically stable (SBP 110/70 mmHg) without severe symptoms, such as syncope, angina, or hypotension. Hospital admission with telemetry is usually unnecessary for this patient's rhythm and symptom severity. Also, the rhythm abnormality is diagnosed on the ECG, and therefore, referral to cardiology is already justified.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department by family members with a pulse of 45 bpm. His blood pressure is normal, and he is otherwise asymptomatic. Which of the following ECG findings would most strongly indicate the need for admission with continuous cardiac monitoring and pacing capability?

choices.text: Progressive prolongation of PR intervals culminating in a dropped QRS complex
Fixed PR interval of 280 ms with a QRS complex following every P wave
Regular atrial activity with ventricular complexes occurring after every fourth P wave
Sinus rhythm with intermittent pauses lasting 2.5 seconds
P waves with 1:1 AV conduction and narrow QRS complexes at 45 bpm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This describes Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) AV block, which is typically a low-risk AV block occurring at the AV nodal level. These patients can often be managed as outpatients unless hemodynamically unstable, as the risk of progression to complete heart block is low.

B) INCORRECT:

This describes first-degree AV block with a prolonged but fixed PR interval. First-degree AV block is considered low-risk and does not require admission unless the patient is symptomatic or has other high-risk features. Outpatient monitoring is typically sufficient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This describes high-grade AV block (4:1 block) where two or more consecutive P waves do not generate a ventricular response. High-grade AV block carries a high risk of progression to complete heart block and sudden cardiac death, requiring immediate admission for continuous cardiac monitoring with pacing capability.

D) INCORRECT:

Brief pauses under 3 seconds are generally considered benign findings, especially in asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic patients. These pauses may be related to increased vagal tone and typically do not require immediate admission unless associated with syncope or hemodynamic instability.

E) INCORRECT:

This describes sinus bradycardia, which is a normal variant that can be seen in athletes or patients on rate-controlling medications. Isolated sinus bradycardia in a hemodynamically stable patient does not require admission unless there are other concerning features or symptoms.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of intermittent dizziness and fatigue. Last week, she nearly fainted while watching television. She also reports episodes of rapid, irregular heartbeats that last for several minutes and then stop suddenly, after which she feels particularly lightheaded. Her medical history is significant for hypertension. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 52/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 134/78 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. An in-office ECG shows a sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Second-degree atrioventricular (AV) block can cause bradycardia, dizziness, and syncope due to impaired conduction from the atria to the ventricles. However, AV block does not cause episodes of rapid, irregular heartbeats. AV block is a disorder of conduction, not impulse formation, and does not cause a tachyarrhythmia.

B) CORRECT:

Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) refers to dysfunction of the sinoatrial (SA) node, often due to age-related fibrosis. This patient's presentation is classic for the tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome variant of SSS. This condition is characterized by alternating periods of atrial tachyarrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, causing her palpitations) and bradycardia (causing her baseline low pulse, dizziness, and fatigue). The profound lightheadedness after her palpitations cease is a key feature caused by overdrive suppression, where the rapid tachyarrhythmia temporarily suppresses the already dysfunctional SA node, leading to a prolonged sinus pause upon termination. Diagnosis often requires ambulatory ECG monitoring (e.g., Holter monitor) to capture the intermittent arrhythmias.

C) INCORRECT:

Carotid sinus hypersensitivity can cause syncope or presyncope in older adults due to an exaggerated vagal response to carotid sinus stimulation (e.g., head turning, tight collar). This patient's near-syncope occurred without a clear trigger. Furthermore, this condition does not account for her episodes of rapid, irregular palpitations.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasovagal syncope is a common cause of presyncope and syncope resulting from a neurally mediated reflex that causes transient bradycardia and hypotension. While vasovagal syncope explains the near-fainting episode, it does not account for this patient's underlying bradycardia (pulse of 52/min) or recurrent episodes of rapid, irregular palpitations.

E) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation accounts for this patient's episodes of rapid, irregular heartbeats. However, this diagnosis alone does not account for the underlying sinus bradycardia (pulse of 52/min) or the profound lightheadedness that occurs specifically after the tachycardia terminates. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation represents the tachycardic component of a broader syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is characterized by both bradycardia (dizziness, fatigue, and low pulse) and paroxysmal tachycardia (palpitations). The lightheadedness that occurs after the rapid heartbeats resolve is a key clue.
